summary: Child workflows invoked via execute_child_workflow don't display as relationships in the parent workflow or dashboard UI, despite running and completing. They only appear in the parent's execution history.
userImpact: Users cannot track or monitor child workflow relationships when using execute_child_workflow with abandon parent_close_policy, breaking observability of hierarchical workflows.
rootCause: Child workflows started but not fully accepted by server before parent workflow completes, causing them to become no-ops or not register as relationships.
proposedFix: Wait for child workflow start requests to be accepted by server before parent completes using Future.all_of().wait() to ensure all child starts are properly registered.
workaround: Add a sleep delay after invoking child workflows and before parent returns, allowing sufficient time for child workflow starts to be accepted.
resolutionDetails: Solution provided in comments: use Future.all_of to wait for all child workflow start requests to complete before parent workflow finishes.
keyQuote: Future doesn't have a 'started', you'd wait until the future completes which represents start completing
